instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power all ports cycle
threads.message: working on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  2.4,64,8tb,5600m great specs, and great condition, board is clean, no liquid damage, all ports amp meter just cycle on off wont even display voltage, just lights up and goes back off, looks like 5v .3 amp on all ports all cycling after 1 sec

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power all ports cycle
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on CC1/2 pins of all ports.
Also check the same at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and F7000/1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power all ports cycle
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on CC1/2 pins of all ports mot sure what u mean by CC1/2 pins
 <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 
 F7000/1. diode mode .393

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power all ports cycle
threads.message:
Don't you find "CC1" and "CC2" on schematic???
Shouldn't be dificult to find them around <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips.

Read more threads on the forum, not just yours.
Unless you are not interested to gather free useful information.
